text:
The first video of this series
examined what digital transformation
is and why it's important.
Now we’ll discuss implementation.

First, identify who will be responsible
for implementing digital
transformation for your organization.

The ‘who’ in a successful
digital transformation

is not just a single person
or job role.

Instead, it's a blend of organization,
culture, and people.

Second, define how you will
transform your organization.

The ‘how’ in a successful
digital transformation

starts with defining the transformation
vision, strategy, and governance,

and completing the transformation
process.

A digital transformation
vision is a concise description
of the end state of the transformation.

An example for a manufacturing
business could be,

“Facilitate a zero-downtime
assembly process.” Or for a retail

company, “Make
the shopping experience

convenient and adaptable
to changing customer demands.”

A digital transformation
strategy is a high-level

plan to accomplish a digital
transformation initiative.

The strategy should include
the following elements,

at a minimum: detailed objectives
that are derived from the vision

and target business outcomes,
stakeholder analysis, and guiding
principles.

It should also include critical
success factors with key performance

indicators, or KPIs, to measure
success, and a digital transformation
organizational structure.

Digital transformation
governance is a framework

that includes precepts such
as policies, principles,
and tenets.

It also includes roles and responsibilities;
a funding model; standards;

detailed KPIs and metrics;
change management; and tools

that support the automation
of operations.

The main governance body, such
as the business or technical

review board, is responsible
for breaking down organizational

barriers and sharing data to foster
collaboration.

After defining and adopting
the digital transformation

vision, strategy, and governance,
it is time to start delivering.

The focus should be on implementing
a minimum viable product

that delivers business value
and then scaling and refining
that solution.

We advocate taking this rapid
minimalistic approach instead

of drawn-out proofs of concept
as the best way to balance

learning and assessment
while still delivering
value.
